item.title: About
item.description: Christian is a Masters student in the Systems Science Department at Portland State University. His academic interests are in machine learning, aritificial intelligence, data science, statistics, and systems modeling.

item.title: Bar Chart With Faceting Brief
item.description: library(tidyverse) library(gapminder) library(reshape2) library(wesanderson) library(readr) How to Read it and What to look for: A bar plot is used to compare members of a category on the x axis to some common continuous measure on the y axis. This allows for easy comparison between groups. Faceting is an option which allows for display of two bar plots that you would like to compare. The same x axis and y axis variables are selected and an additional categorical variable is chosen to define the subset of the data being displayed in each graph.

item.title: Dot Plot Brief
item.description: How to Read it and What to look for The dot plot is a type of graph used to display the distribution of a continuous variable, often grouping by category. To read a dot plot , the reader should look for how mass is distributed along the plot. This indicates the frequency of observations at the corresponding value. Example: #Spread of countries gdp by continent gap_country <- gapminder %>% group_by(continent, country, year) %>% filter(year == "2007") ggplot(gap_country,aes(x = continent, y = gdpPercap, fill = continent ))+ geom_dotplot(binwidth = .

item.title: Side By Side Barchart
item.description: library(tidyverse) library(gapminder) library(reshape2) library(wesanderson) How to Read it and What to look for: The side by side bar chart is used to vizualize multiple categorical variables and a continuous variable simultaneously. The continuous variable is diplayed on the common y axis to enable comparison. A categorical variable is displayed on the x axis and another categorical variable is used to define what the side by side bars represent. Data: This example uses the gapminder dataset which details global gross domestic product.

item.title: Violin Plot Brief
item.description: library(tidyverse) library(gapminder) library(reshape2) library(wesanderson) library(readr) How to Read it and What to look for: A violin plot is used to display a distribution of a variable often split up across mulitple levels of a category for comparison purposes. The mass is displayed in an appealing symmetrical refelction resembling a violin. Data: This example uses the gapminder dataset which details global gross domestic product. The dataset contains measures of gdp by country and continent over time.

item.title: Home
item.description: Welcome! This website is a portfolio of some of my machine machine learning and data science projects. Please explore examples of my work by clicking the PROJECTS link. See more detailed code examples by clicking the github icon below for a link to my repository.
